title: Which country will win the most gold medals in Brazil this summer?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Wimpy revision of my earlier prediction that China would win the most golds. I was wrong.
OK, no one can touch US now, just 12 medals to still be contested, and they are 16 ahead.
USA have the best female athletes in the world.  Until china host the Olympics again the US will win the most gold medals.
The wrong question to ask really. The US has the largest population size apart from China but its sports programs are much more advanced. The right question takes into account the population size.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Team GB are contesting 17 gold medals today / tomorrow which means it is still mathematically possible for them to take more golds than US but SO unlikely! China are only contesting 14 - so even if they win them all, and US lose all their 21 possible medals in the next two days, China are still behind.
only 2 days left, even schedule looks to maintain USA lead

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/19/world/asia/lower-medal-count-in-rio-rattles-chinas-olympics-obsession.html?emc=edit_th_20160819&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 "Before the Games, some Chinese news reports predicted that the country’s athletes could win up to 36 gold medals. Many foreign analysts forecast similar numbers. At the lower end of predictions, Gracenote, a sports and entertainment data company, predicted China would win 29 gold medals. “I think China will finish second,” Simon Gleave, the head of analysis at Gracenote Sports, said Thursday . .  . He estimated that China could end up with 24 gold medals when the Games finish on Sunday.  . . . “They still have a lot of events to come where they’ve got big favorites,” he said, noting the strong Chinese competitors in canoeing, diving and badminton.
. . . 
"In Rio, Chinese gymnasts have won two bronze medals. In London in 2012, they won five gold medals and 12 over all; in Beijing in 2008, 11 gold medals and 18 in total. Chinese athletes have also performed worse than in previous Games in their other traditional strengths of badminton and swimming . . . China’s medal shortfalls, Mr. Gleave said, “have been due to an underperformance in a limited number of sports.”

Stopped updating after day 7 as seemed to be a foregone conclusion. Using sports illustrated predictions of medals will keep a record of how well China and US are doing vs predictions. +1 for gold won which was not predicted, -1 for gold not won which was predicted.
 End Day 2: US 0 (includes -1 for Womens doubles tennis); China -1.
End Day 3: US 1 China -3 also betfair odds have fallen from 1.2 to 1.05 in last 24hours. Betfair and GJo consensus quite close before this.
End Day 4: US 2 China -4.
End day 5: US 1 China -6.
End Day 6: US 4 China-7
End Day 7: US 4 China -11. (includes -3 for US for womens tennis singles, doubles and soccer)
http://www.si.com/olympics/2016/08/01/rio-2016-olympics-medal-picks-predictions-projected-medal-count
Injury to Simone Biles probably biggest threat to US topping gold medal table.
I would have gone with this at any time (can I do it for Tokyo 2020?). Came late to the party, it's a done deal - so 100 rather than a 99 or so per cent.
It's still POSSIBLE for either China or UK to get enough gold medals to pass US - but it is very unlikely. I think US will probably finish on about 38 golds, UK on about 25 and China on 23.....
Gold medal count. As of 8/17/16 is USA-30, GB-19, & China-19 and counting.
Simply based on previous year records, USA claims the most medals every year. However China is the fastest growing medal winner, so this could change the record in the next decade or so.

At 75% and with 28 medals (the next ones along are Britain with 19 medals and China with 17 medals), it is appears unlikely for this result to be overturned, even if there are sports coming up that Britain/China are exceptionally good.

With more than two thirds of the total available already awarded, USA leads with 28, well ahead of China's 17, with Great Britain currently at 19. China is expected to do well in Table Tennis and Badminton, but the US is likely to counter that with more athletics golds. 
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/17/worst-olympic-flop-china-smarts-as-it-lags-behind-team-gb-in-med/
"China is forecast to win 25 gold medals in Rio, although some fans believe even that estimate is too generous."
It is impossible to overcome the current lead in the remaining few days.
USA is so far ahead but Great Britain and China may get a little closer before it's over.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
As of this moment, it's USA 24, China 13.

With 24 gold vs 13, and 60 total medals vs 41 this isn't competitive.

Raising from 96% to 99%.

Status as of today : USA 15, China 11
Moving US up 5% to stay ahead of consensus
Affirming pre-games forecast. This one is closing very late IMO - not sure that there'll be much 'forecasting' required by the last day of the Games.
Done deal, I think. China still has badminton and table tennis but US has the many competitions in track and field to look forward to.
As of 8/11/-6 the count stands at USA 11 versus  China 10 Hold medals. Nip and Tuck race til the end for the Gold medal count. Go USA!!!!!🇺🇸🇺🇸🇺🇸🇺🇸

Loving the neck and neck competition. I am still retaining 50/50!
US has caught up with China's gold total, and now has ..... 8 gold, 8 silver, 8 bronze.... Which was also the opening date of the Chinese Olympics.

http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/rio-2016/2016/08/04/team-usa-rio-olympics-overall-medal-count/87974688/ "Gracenote Sports, a statistics and information company that runs a popular prediction model for every Olympics,  . . [has] China predicted to get 29 golds to the USA’s 39. A separate predictive model used by Sports Illustrated says the U.S. and China will both get 45 golds . . . 
. . .
". . . the [American] collegiate sports system allows for proficiency in a wide variety of disciplines. Furthermore, the structure of the Olympics is of some assistance.  The USA is really the only nation to be very dominant in both track and field and swimming,” . . .  “Both of those sports . . . offer a disproportionately large number of available medals compared to other sports. . . .
. . . 
" . . .  the structure of the Games schedule often helps the U.S. remain at or near the top all the way through the Olympics. “With swimming at the start of the program, women’s gymnastics in the middle and track towards the end, the USA has strong possibilities spaced all the way through,” 
~~~~~~~
http://www.teamusa.org/News/2016/August/05/Team-USA-Predicted-To-Lead-Medal-Count-In-Rio "Gracenote has Ledecky winning three golds (400 free, 800 free and 4x200 freestyle) . . Biles . . . four gold medals (balance beam, floor exercise, individual all-around and team). . . Phelps will win four more gold medals — in the 100 fly, 200 IM, 4x100 medley and 4x200 freestyle 
~~~~~~~
http://www.ibtimes.com/what-country-will-win-most-gold-medals-2016-rio-olympics-betting-odds-favor-usa-china-2397711 "The U.S. has the best odds to win the most gold medals, by far, as a 2/13 betting favorite. . . . In Rio, the U.S. has been given 5/7 odds to win more than 42.5 gold medals. "China has been given the best chance to unseat the U.S. as the most dominant Olympic country with 4/1 odds. It wasn’t too long ago when China did win more gold medals than the U.S., and they did so handily when they were the host nation. China led the 2008 Beijing Olympics with 51 gold medals, holding a 15-medal advantage over the U.S. "The men’s basketball team is a 1/16 favorite to win the gold medal . . .  The women’s basketball team is expected to be nearly as dominant with 1/14 odds. "Michael Phelps is . . .  favored to win the 100-meter butterfly and the 200-meter individual medley, though he is a slight underdog in the 200-meter butterfly. "While China could make things interesting for the U.S. when it comes to gold medals, no other country is expected to come close. Great Britain has the third best odds at 50/1, while three other nations—Australia, Germany and Russia—all have 66/1 odds. In 2012, Great Britain finished in third place as the host nation, racking up 29 gold medals.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Elsewhere I read that Biles could win 5 golds:  team gold, all-around, vault, beam and floor.   At the moment China leads in golds: 8 to our 6.  I do not know if any of our "expected" golds failed to materialize, or if we're on track with predictions.

Both Ledecky and Phelps have landed their initial Golds and seem on course for their predicted multiple gold medals in the pool, which as per earlier analysis, will be the key determinant taking US to the top position in the medals tally ahead of China. Raising US to 96% from 88%.

1.USA is mirroring Venus and Serena Williams in shock defeats. USA is beaten in both golds and total medal count. But it is not merely being beaten by the powerhouse dragon, but even by the likes of Hungary. Languishing miserably in 5th place. Australia with 3 golds, Italia, Korea and Hungary with 2 each are ahead.
The dragon crucially is ahead 3 to 1 in golds, and 8 to 7 in total medal count.  http://www.theguardian.com/sport/ng-interactive/2016/aug/05/rio-olympics-2016-medal-table-and-results-in-full
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/07/rio-olympics-2016-serena-and-venus-williams-suffer-shock-doubles/ 2. A lot of countries are winning medals for the first time ever. This is strictly bad for both dominant nations. Unfortunately it isn't yet clear which one will suffer more. "Vietnam's Hoang Xuan Vinh secured its first Olympic gold medal in any sport, winning the men's 10-metre air pistol event."
http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-07/vietnam-wins-first-ever-olympic-gold-medal/7698692 3. Australia and Hungary have done very, very well. This prediction now seems very likely. Australia predicted to win a national record 20 gold medals at Rio Olympics by Sports Illustrated
http://www.foxsports.com.au/olympics/australia-predicted-to-win-a-national-record-20-gold-medals-at-rio-olympics-by-sports-illustrated/news-story/95786c84a135644d47542f9eefd925a6?nk=1ae956b71d0c955996d518648f026d0b-1470609053 Even though this is only day 2 and the likely spread between No 1 and No 2 will be a few golds. So how well other countries do is vital since that will tip the balance one way or the other.
China dropped another 2 Golds I had forecast they would win (42 to 34 now), so assuming Phelps, Ledecky and Biles deliver, I think it may be already over. Bumping US up to 96%.

I think US probably edge it over China, given 2012 results and the medal table today - but I'm not ready to dismiss China yet - they had significantly more medals in 2008 than US... and Russia is less of a threat this year.

Women's Air foil takes one away from China and gives it to the US, so that's like 2 medals

Shooting is over; USA gold, China silver, and bronze.
US takes gold in Women's 10m Air Rifle, which was meant to be a nailed on medal for China (got silver and bronze). Moves forecast to 42 to 36 so shifting forecast up by 12% for US.
Updating my medal prediction before the games start I now have US on 41 and China on 37, so moving up US to 62%

Superpowers always win overall. It's just that simple.

To me, this suggests that our bench is deeper, our athletes will be fresher, and less will ride on any one person.

Scaling back on US dominance following Goldman Sachs projections.

Sports Illustrated predicts a tie in the gold medal count. "In the event of a tie in the gold medal count, we will use the total number of medals to serve as a tiebreaker." I doubt very much the USA can match Zhongguo's medal tally. Given that Australia is predicted to do well, US will bring fewer medals from the pool this time around. 16 Gold medals in 2012 for USA, but the current Australian team has been eating Skippy for breakfast. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics#Medal_summary "LARGELY underwhelming times at US selection trials has left Australia’s swimmers sitting pretty in the world rankings leading into the Rio Olympics. Australia held its selection trials three months ago and the times have stood up well. The nation still has seven swimmers ranked No.1 in the world based on 2016 times, boding well for its prospects in both individual and relay events. Mitch Larkin’s 100m backstroke time from trials was the only world-leading mark eclipsed after the Americans revealed their best."
http://www.foxsports.com.au/olympics/underwhelming-us-swim-trials-leave-australian-swimmers-sitting-pretty-for-rio-but-theres-a-catch/news-story/e1b590b7f5883296e916b39cf5408b39 "The predictions, which are broken down into individual events, would see the USA top the medal tally with 45 gold, 31 silver and 39 bronze, ahead of China (45, 25, 15) and Australia (20, 21, 8)."
http://www.smh.com.au/sport/olympics/rio-2016/rio-olympics-2016-sports-illustrated-predicts-record-golden-haul-for-australia-20160725-gqczho.html My own count based on Olympic contingent size and medals in last 3 Olympics has the USA losing out.

The situation with the Russian team, ZIKA and the water sports venues all add up to some unpredictability. I suspect team rosters have been changed at the very lasst moment by other teams scared of exposure. Russia has had a turbulent build up to this summer’s Olympic Games, with 110 of Russia’s 387 competitors so far banned from competing. Their exclusion follows a damning report by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) on the “state-sponsored” doping program within the country.

only few russians , gymnastics  chinese will win most gold medals in gymnastics, swim mostly us, athletics by us and other (jameika, african, european),
Russia is definitely out because of doping bans. I am not certain, but i think the ban on Russians is going to help USA more.
Previous results in summer games show USA getting most medals and at this time there is no information to suggest that the brazil games will be different

US consistently wins many medals. China is improving, but not as consistent. Russia consistently wins, but they are expected to have many athletes banned for PEDs. Great Britain does not consistently win enough medals, nor does any other country. As another country, Brazil has a home field advantage.
With China still being unphased by doping leaks and russia back in the games.
Just saw Russia have avoided a complete ban.
The US will be in their own time zones.
USA will dominate - as usual. sadly.

My first prediction is based on hunch alone. I'm curious to register my intuitive scores before analysing in greater detail, after which I'm sure my allocations will change significantly. Russia are not going so 0%. GB and other countries are outsiders, and thus receive outsider percentages. Then it is close between China and US, with the former nosing marginally ahead. China only seriously compete on the world sporting stage in the Olympics, hence their best athletes go into Olympic sports (unlike in the US). In addition, we are 8 years on from Beijing when many young aspiring athletes were sold a dream to compete (I was in China during that time - it was powerful!). Add those two elements to a sizeable population and the pedigree should be impressive.

Even the Chinese don't think they will win

The analysis, based on data collected at the most recent related events, was released as the 30-day countdown to the opening of the Games on Aug 5 got underway."
Upping the US's odds of taking most golds due to GJP consensus for the moment

According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
US Olympic trials finished last week with a very strong team selected.

USA has won most gold metal in every summer Olympics since 98' (exception of Bejing where host China took 1st) and was 2nd in 92 vs a collection of former Soviet states. It therefore is the clear front runner. China's Improving athletics program and strong showing in 08 make it the next most likely nation. Russia and Great Britten are usually strong, however the disqualification of the Russian track team, and Britten's Olympic hangover lower the probability of them winning.

Based on recent historical results. The PRC did get the most gold medals in the Beijing Summer Olympics but I have to wonder whether that has anything to do with the native athletes being more accustomed to the chunky air of much of urban China.
Updating to zero out Russia and increase odds of USA domination.

There were 302 gold medals available in London 2012, of which the US won 46 and China 38. Importantly, the US dominated in the areas where most medals are available: athletics and swimming. In addition, they had lots of silver and bronze medals in these sports too, giving them greater scope to improve. Britain peaked for a home Olympics, London 2012; and Russia has potential drugs problems - athletes from both countries are also more likely to struggle with the weather.
China's last win was on home soil, which always comes with a concentrated push. This year it's closer to the US and there's no reason to think they will do any worse than 2012's first place finish.

I believe that the US has a three-fold advantage over the other nations. First there is a great diversity in the population so that there are multiple nationalities in the nation which perform better on average in any one event. Second Large population size so a fair amount of the worlds exceptional athletes will be located in the country. Third there's a shit ton of time money and status devoted to finding the best athletes in america.
China has a massive population. But they lack the diversity. Also lack the will to put in sufficient time and effort into finding best athletes in games that aren't bejing.
Other country: Brazil may be in with a chance. They're a large, diverse nation and have a home field advantage this year. At the very least strong showing

There are 379 athletes from China and 537 athletes from USA.  Chine has more popullation for choice. In China, the main sports are weightlifting, swimming, badminton, gymnastics. Competitors have a doping problem in weightlifting. China athlets are more diversifyied. In USA, the main sports are swimming, track&field. USA had strong competitors from Kenia, Britan and Jamaika in 2015 in their major sport.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

Gracenote's July forecast gives US 41 gold to China's 31.  This count should not be affected by Russian suspensions.
The Russian track and field (athletics) team is still included in the medal count, though not projected to win any "Gold" medals.  
http://sportsdemo1.gracenote.com/documentation/vmt#demo
Slight adjustment - US up; China down
I am assuming that Russian athletes face either an outright ban or the need to prove they are clear of drugs. I assume that all drug testing will be rigorous.
Have to go with the home team.
Russians not competing in track and field
GB will focus on solving the problems caused by Brexit. The Olympics are absolutely irrelevant for them. Therefore I downrated GB by 5% relative to my forecast 4 weeks ago.
USA has the best chance China will not be far behind and could overtake USA
With Russia dq'ed I think China and the USA have the best chances of winning the most gold medals.  I'm just not sure if the USA will come out on top.
Russia won't be competing in track and field, so US has more opportunity to pick up medals.
The odds are oh so ever in their favor.
In 2012, USA had 46 gold; China had 38. If there was a 4 medal swing, that puts it at a tie, and tie-breaker is total medals.

Likely to be dominated by USA and China. GB will see bounce factor after home games and Russia will potentially struggle due to doping consequences. Australia and Germany may beat GB (50% chance imo) too so are ruled out again due to that.
I think China has changed its training methods

Russia will likely decline due to the track & field ban.  Great Britain should take the usual "previous host nation dip" in 2016.  No other country shows a likelihood of doubling or tripling their previous gold medal haul. That leaves just the USA and China to consider.  With the exception of the AOC's prediction from December 2015, other medal predictions that I have found show the USA at the top of the table.  Additionally, the USA had 8 more gold medals in 2012 and 7 more silver or bronze medals.  While the USA will probably decline from 2012, the increased number of other medals points to additional potential chances for moving up to a gold.

In support of China:
-A linear trend based solely on the last 5 games puts China above the US by 5 to 6 golds (see below for trend analysis).
-The Chinese have made it clear that they want to be a dominant player on the world stage and their government, culture, and economy are uniquely positioned to crank out Olympians.  In support of USA:
-The trend mentioned above includes the 2008 Beijing games. Historically the "home-team advantage" has been huge in the Olympics, leading me to wonder if this is a statistical fluke. Removing the 2008 result puts China and the US at a statistical tie. If we further assume that the US would have won many of the golds that China ended up winning it puts the US ahead.
-Newsweek reports that Chinese sport schools are struggling in the new economy (http://www.newsweek.com/china-rio-de-janeiro-olympics-2016-training-huang-qin-beijing-461351), including a nearly 33% drop in the total number of schools. -Chinese media statements have also attempted to downplay predictions of Chinese success. 
-Last, most predictions show the US winning. I was able to find one prediction from the Australian Olympic Committee that showed China winning, but they also predicted Russia to win in 2008 (Russia ended up placing 4th).

With Russian light-athletes being more or less banned for doping we can easy put their score to zero http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2016/04/16/rio-2016-olympics-medal-table-who-has-most-gold-medals/ Looking at the past Olympics there has been a steady increase in total medals, this year at Rio 301 or up for grabs. And, a host country tend to have good results but 4-8 years later return to old patterns. Australia is a good example and Great Britian will be the next. 2000: 11, 2004: 9, 2008:19, 2012: 29, 2016: maybe with some luck 20, but likely less This brings the question truly between China and USA, whereas the US is pretty consistent: 2000: 37, 2004: 36, 2008: 36, 2012: 46 (English speaking advantage, maybe), 2016: easily above 40. If the Russians are disqualified in track/field events, the USA could get a few more as these are typically good disciplines for them. China, after their own Olympics will be down, plus with heightened control on doping as we saw with the Russians, their unnatural edge will be reduced. Should be below 40. However, without Phelps on the US-Swim team it is likely that less gold will be won, likely all, so 4. Meaning, USA: >40, China: <40. Pretty close to call. I think it comes down to doping, if the Chinese get caught it is the US, if not China. Even the obvious Russian activities took months and years to expose and get a judgment. Likelihood not high. Taking this study into account, based on 2015 performances, China might have the upper-hand. http://sports.ndtv.com/olympics-2016/news/253250-china-on-right-track-to-top-medals-tally-at-2016-rio-olympics-study My guess: USA: 38 China: 42 - 85% China.
Checked out this link for 5 minutes and revising downwards on US slightly: http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/predicted-2016.htm
Revising Russia down to 0% from 1% because while I think that there is a higher probability of Russia winning than Great Britain, I think the probability is less than 0.5%.

Just looked at the tables here and used my intuition, also paying attention to the fact that China and Great Britain were the host countries in 2008 and 2012 respectively and got more medals (presumably) in those years as a result: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics_medal_table
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics_medal_table

Computed a base rate via the following: Found a weighted average for average medals since lesser medals (Silver, Bronze) can be a good indicator of a nation's propensity to win gold in future games (Gold = 1, Silver = .5, Bronze = .33) for USA, China, Russia, and UK over last three Olympics (2004, 2008, 2012). Imposed a 21% host country penalty (based on medal jump vs expected) on average medal count for China in 2008 and UK in 2012. Projected 2016 medal count for all countries based on previous trends with 50% regression towards mean (e.g. projected the US to win 71.1 average medals in 2016 ( 1.4 more than in 2012, based on average increase of 2.8 medals per Olympics with a 50% regression toward the mean). Plugged medal counts for 2004 - 2016 for each country into a normal distribution, calculated z scores, and found that no country (other than China) has a greater than 0.5% chance of scoring above the USA mean (68 medals). China has a 6% chance of scoring above the USA mean. Compared this against the outside view (top 4 google results), which all indicate that the USA is projected to win the most gold medals.

Most forecasts have USA winning 39-43 gold medals. These are generally all in well followed sports and when you look at the individuals on the lists and what they have them winning, its hard to argue with the forecast. So the question really boils down to three things: Can China win more than 39 medals?
Will the superstar USA trio of Phelps, Ledecky and Biles deliver the expected 9-12 gold medals?
Will the Zika virus prevent some of the athletes travelling? Starting with China question the @Enthu link (http://olympicmedalspredictions.com/countries.php) gives what looks like a reasonable baseline of 26 before Badminton and Diving, but they only have China winning one medal in Badminton and zero in Diving (I assume the latter is an error of omission on the part of the website). Its entirely feasible that the Chinese clean sweep both (they got 11/13 in London 2012), but using the 2015 championships for both sports as a rough baseline lets assume 3 for badminton and 7 in diving which brings us to a total of 38 medals - I fully realise all the experts have China on less but I can't really see where I have gone wrong so if anybody has a link to individual medals by sport it would be appreciated. In terms of the trio for Phelps and Ledecky, we will know better by the end of this month after the US Olympic swim trials, but the US team has enough depth that there isn't much reason to go against their forecasted medal win for the moment. The same can be said for Biles whose preparation continues to go well according to all reports. In terms of the Zika virus, I don't think it hurts one country more than the other, but it is something to look out for in case some of the expected medal winners begin to drop out. So where does that leave the forecast: I will start on 68% USA and 32% China, until I see both the results of the US swim trials and hopefully more detail of the individual breakdowns of the experts.

China has a state-sponsored program to develop Olympic athletes in EVERY discipline, thus they win lots of medals in sports that few outside the sport even know exist (various sailing and shooting events, for example). There is no reason to think that program has not matured even more since the last Olympics.

I decided to look at two key factors. The first is a four-year average of Olympic gold performance, and the second is a projection of gold medal winners, based on the current world rankings in each of the 306 gold medal sports.  The four-year average is easy to verify. I picked 1996 as my starting point because it was the first post-USSR/Unified Team competition. After careful consideration I decided to omit 1996 because the results of China, the USA and Great Britain are so different from the four following years, which left the 2000, 2004, 2008 and 2012 Olympic years as my performance baseline. Looking at those years, I looked to see whether gold medal wins or total medal count was more predictive of gold medal success in the following Olympics, and found the r2 correlation was highest with gold-to-gold. My second piece of work is harder to verify. It’s too much to post the projections 306 gold medal events here, but in each case I endeavoured to find the most recent world rankings relevant to each Olympic gold medal event. In each case, I took the ranking leader and assumed that he/she/they would win gold for his/her/their respective country. Here’s what I found:  - USA: four-year average of 39 gold, projection of 36 gold
- China: four-year average of 37 gold, projection of 37 gold
- Russia: four-year average of 27 gold, projection* of 20 gold
- Great Britain: four-year average of 17 goal, projection of 19 gold * Russia may not be allowed to compete in Athletics, which would put two gold medals at risk, but not benefit the other major countries listed here. There was another drop-off from Russia/Great Britain to countries like South Korea, Germany and Australia. As I see it, it’s highly unlikely that any country other than China or the USA wins the event. Russia is a historic power, but the country has dropped from 32 golds in 2000 to 28 in 2004, down to just 24 in 2012. My projections suggest another fall. Great Britain has been very successful at the last two Olympics by its historic standards, but realistically its high-water mark is third place. Some other country may leapfrog the British and the Russians, but surpassing both China and the USA is highly implausible.  The key question here is how to balance China and the United States. Our four-year average gives USA a slight edge, and probably more than that when we consider the bump China got from the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, in which the country won 51 gold. However, the projections very, very slightly favour China.  With that in mind, I’m going to round Russia’s chances up to 1 percent, and give the United States a 50-to-49 percent edge over China. I’m convinced based on recent world rankings and Olympic performance that this is a much closer battle than the consensus on this site would suggest.

There is a very informative site that has come up, which individually identifies the likely medal winners in each event. It is not clear who has put up the site, but their predictions on each event seems to be on the mark. You can select individual countries from the drop down box.
http://olympicmedalspredictions.com/countries.php The only difference between US and China is *three people*: Michael Phelps, Katie Ledecky and Simone Biles. They are expected to win 3+2+3 Golds individually. In addition, all three are expected to contribute at least another Gold by boosting the team events. All put together that is a haul of 11 Golds. The website projects US - 39 and China - 27. 
http://olympicmedalspredictions.com/index.php
The surprisingly high proportion of Golds won by US, as opposed to Silver like in the case of China, is mainly because of these three people.  Once Olympics starts, we will know whether US will finish on top simply by watching the performance of the three. It helps that both the swimming and gymnastics events are held in the *first week*. Even if all the three collapse, US can still finish on top, but the odds on that would only be 50%.
---------------------------------- The more reliable and granular analysis of Gracenote expects the three to contribute 13 Golds !

To the last Olympic games tally and added the following considerations:
- Zika may keep some Americans from joining (thus deducting from the 100% that would have been allocated to US)
- China's economy saw a downturn since the last Olympics, thus making the chance of them gaining the most gold medals very slim (but not zero)
- Great Britain was the third in 2012, while being the host, which doesn't bode well for them this year
- Russia is in the middle of an effort to show the world how good they are - so they have the biggest (but still slim) chance to upset the US domination
- and, for now, I still keep an eye for an upset from another contender (Germany, Brazil or someone else)

Looking at all 5 games since 1996, after the former Soviet Union's team had split into several countries, the USA has won the most gold medals in 4. It came second in 2008, when China won the most (but with host nation advantage). In the last three games, the US and China have  occupied the top two spots.  Without knowing anything about the standing of individual participants, I'll go with the historical base rate at this time. Things that may affect the base rate include (1) whether leading athletes from the US will choose not to go to Brazil because of Zika (unlikely in my opinion after having trained for years) and (2) whether an apparently improved drug detection regime will deter potential winners (depends whether China also had a system similar to that of Russia).

During the 2012 Olympics, the USA led the gold medal count with 46, followed by China with 38 and Great Britain with 29.   Parting from those numbers, and counting on there not being known cause for a trend change this year, I will start with a high 90% change for the USA.

WARNING: I have some strong assumptions going on here, including the consistency of an outside group's projections and their normalcy. Additionally, I've assumed that country's medals are won independently of each other, when in reality, as a country wins a gold medal, it prevents another country from getting that medal. This is to simplify the analysis, but I think the final point remains the same: this should be a pretty straightforward "win" for the US. I used Gracenote's 2012 Olympic prediction data [http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/predicted-2012.htm] to come up with an estimated probability from their 2016 forecasts [http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/predicted-2016.htm]. Using the 2012 data, I found that the root-mean-square deviation is 6. [sqrt((36-46)^2+(38-32)^2+...)] I'll be using this as the standard deviation for each variable. That means that the difference between 2 groups has standard deviation 8.5. [sqrt(6^2+6^2)] Their 2016 estimates show the following gold medal predictions: USA-42, China-31, Russia-22, Australia-18, GB-17, Germany-15, Japan-12, South Korea-12, France-10, Brazil-9. Thus, P(USA>China)=90%, P(USA>Russia)=98%, and P(USA>Aus, et al.)>99%. That means the US has an 88% chance of beating them all. [.9*.98] P(China>USA)=10%, P(China>Russia)=86%, P(China>Aus)=94%, P(China>GB)=95%, and P(China>Germany)=97%. That means China has an 8% chance of beating them all. P(Russia>USA)=2%, and P(Russia>China)=14%, which already puts Russia under 1%. All put together, Gracenote predicts the USA will have a dominating lead over any other competitor in gold medals and medals overall. The only country that will come close appears to be China. Just as a reasonability check, in London 2012, the US won 46, China 38, GB 29, and Russia 24. In the end, it'll be fun to watch! The returns of Michael Phelps and Usain Bolt, the US Women's soccer team trying to get the double crown (World Cup/Olympic gold), the reintroduction of golf... plus Zika, filthy water, and potentially violent demonstrations! All in all should be a spectacle of both the good and crazy varieties.

This link provides results from four separate prediction exercises for the medals tally.
It is 2 out of 3 in favor of US. If we count the Noland survey as well, it is 3 out of 4 is favor of US. 
http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/predicted-2016.htm
That suggests a base rate of 75% for US vs. 25% for China. Details of the concerned models are given here.
http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/rankings-predicted.htm However, if you check the forecasts made for 2012 games, the 'Benchmark Analysis' prediction (the only one which says China will top this year) was totally wrong since it called for Russia to top the medals tally that year. So I am inclined to doubt their prediction this year as well. 
http://www.topendsports.com/events/summer/medal-tally/predicted-2012.htm In addition, Barra called it wrong in 2012, as he gave the top slot to China that year. The only current predictor which got it right in 2012 was Gracenote. Not a minor achievement since the top country in Beijing 2008 was China by a large margin. So, their call for this year ought to be given far more weight than the others. They have the US winning against China by quite a bit (42 vs. 31). That gives a good safety margin against possible minor errors.
http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/gracenotes-data-analytics-predicts-winners-and-losers-of-2016-rio-olympics-300258218.html All in all, am inclined to give 90% chance to US at this stage. Will adjust once more predictions become available in the months ahead.
